oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Northern Bank of Alabama in Huntsville during Federal occupation

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Banks; Flags; Soldiers; Buildings; Guards; Plazas
Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Indiana - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Alabama - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front and side views of the Northern Bank of Alabama flying United States flag under Federal military occupation. Numerous uniformed soldiers and guards stand in front of the building.

Located on the south corner of West Side Square, the Northern Bank of Alabama is pictured flying the United States flag after occupation by Federal troops. Federl troops first seized Huntsville on April 11, 1862, but were forced to retreat several months later. During the autumn of 1863, occupation forces settled in for the duration of the war. Huntsville escaped large-scale damage because it functioned as a Federal base of operations and housed segments of the Federal Army.
